11institutetext: Helmholtz-Institut für Strahlen- und Kernphysik, Universität Bonn, Germany

Heavy-flavor baryons

Eberhard Klempt and Sebastian Neubert klempt@hiskp.uni-bonn.de
(Received: / Revised version:)
Abstract

This is a contribution to the review “50 Years of Quantum Chromdynamics” edited by F. Gross and E. Klempt, to be published in EPJC. The contribution reviews the properties of baryons with one heavy flavor: the lifetimes of ground states and the spectrum of excited states. The importance of symmetries to understand the excitation spectrum is underlined. An overview of searches for pentaquarks is given.

1 Introduction

Baryons with one heavy quark Q𝑄Q and a light diquark q​q𝑞𝑞qq provide an ideal place to study diquark correlations and the dynamics of the light quarks in the environment of a heavy quark. The heavy quark is almost static and provides the color source to the light quarks. Here, we attempt to understand the dynamics leading to the spectrum of baryons with one heavy quark.

The Review of Particle Physics ParticleDataGroup:2022pth lists 28 charmed baryons (16 with known spin-parity) and 22 bottom baryons (15 with known spin-parity). One doubly charmed state has been detected, the ground state Ξc​c++superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐absent\Xi_{cc}^{++}. (Its isospin partner Ξc​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐\Xi_{cc}^{+} is known as well, with poor evidence and one star in RPP, but we do not count isospin partners separately.) In the decays of the lightest bottom baryon, exotic J/ψ​p𝐽𝜓𝑝J/\psi p states, incompatible with a three-quark configuration, have been have been reported in studies of the reaction Λb→J/ψ​p​K−→subscriptΛ𝑏𝐽𝜓𝑝superscript𝐾\Lambda_{b}\to J/\psi pK^{-} LHCb:2015yax ; LHCb:2019kea . The search for further states and attempts to understand the underlying dynamics of heavy baryons are active fields in particle physics. New information can be expected from the upgrades of LHC, BELLE and J-PARC, and from the new FAIR facility at GSI.

2 Ground states of heavy baryons

2.1 Masses and lifetimes

Table 1 presents masses and life times of the ground states of heavy baryons containing a b𝑏b-quark. Naively, one could expect all these life times to represent the life time of the b𝑏b quark, that they all agree with the life time of the B0superscript𝐵0B^{0} meson. This life time is τB0subscript𝜏superscript𝐵0\tau_{B^{0}}=(1519±plus-or-minus\pm4) fs. Indeed, all life times agree within ∼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10% percent.

This is not at all the case when the b𝑏b-quark is replaced by a c𝑐c-quark (see Table 2). The D0superscript𝐷0D^{0} has a life time τD0=(410.3±1.0)subscript𝜏superscript𝐷0plus-or-minus410.31.0\tau_{D^{0}}=(410.3\pm 1.0) fs, the D+superscript𝐷D^{+} has τD+=(1033±5)subscript𝜏superscript𝐷plus-or-minus10335\tau_{D^{+}}=(1033\pm 5) fs. The life times of charmed baryons are spread over a wide range and do not agree with the life times of D𝐷D mesons. In addition to the decay of the c𝑐c-quark, the c​d¯𝑐¯𝑑c\bar{d} pair in a D0superscript𝐷0D^{0} meson can annihilate into a W+superscript𝑊W^{+}, a process forbidden for the D+superscript𝐷D^{+}. In B𝐵B decays, the corresponding CKM matrix element is small, and this effect is suppressed. Further significant corrections are required to arrive at a consistent picture for the decays of charmed mesons and baryons. The authors of Ref. Gratrex:2022xpm have performed an extensive study of the lifetimes within the heavy quark expansion, and have included all known corrections. The impact of the charmed-quark mass and of the wavefunctions of charmed hadrons were carefully studied. Then, qualitative agreement between their calculations and the experimental data was achieved.

The first state with two charmed quarks, the Ξc​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐\Xi_{cc}^{+} was reported by the SELEX collaboration in two decay modes at a mass of (3518.9±plus-or-minus\pm0.9) MeV and with 5-6σ𝜎\sigma SELEX:2002wqn ; SELEX:2004lln . In later searches, this state was never confirmed. The LHCb collaboration found its doubly charged partner Ξc​c++superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐absent\Xi_{cc}^{++} LHCb:2019epo . Its mass is (3621.6±plus-or-minus\pm0.4) MeV, its life time (25.6±plus-or-minus\pm2.7) fs. Later, the LHCb collaboration reported evidence for a Ξc​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐\Xi_{cc}^{+} baryon at (3623.0±plus-or-minus\pm1.4) MeV LHCb:2021eaf . It is seen with 3-4σ𝜎\sigma only but its mass is better compatible with an interpretation of Ξc​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐\Xi_{cc}^{+} and Ξc​c++superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐absent\Xi_{cc}^{++} as isospin partners. A search for the Ξb​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑏𝑐\Xi_{bc}^{+} remained unsuccessful LHCb:2022fbu .

2.2 The flavor wave function: SU(4)

In this contribution we discuss baryons with one heavy-quark flavor, with either a charm or a bottom quark. Overall, we consider five quarks, u,d,s,c,b𝑢𝑑𝑠𝑐𝑏u,d,s,c,b, but we will not discuss baryons with one light (q=u,d,s𝑞𝑢𝑑𝑠q=u,d,s) and two different heavy quarks like Ξc​b+=(u​c​b)subscriptsuperscriptΞ𝑐𝑏𝑢𝑐𝑏\Xi^{+}_{cb}=(ucb). Thus we can restrict ourselves to SU(4). The four quarks have very different masses, and the SU(4) symmetry is heavily broken, nevertheless it provides a guide to classify heavy-quark baryons. Three-quark baryons can classified according to

4⊗4⊗4=20s⊕20m⊕20m⊕4atensor-product444direct-sumsubscript20ssubscript20msubscript20msubscript4a4\otimes 4\otimes 4=20_{\rm s}\oplus 20_{\rm m}\oplus 20_{\rm m}\oplus 4_{\rm a} (1)

into a fully symmetric 20-plet, two 20-plets of mixed symmetry and a fully antisymmetric 4-plet. In states with one heavy quark only, there is one light quark pair. The light diquark can be decomposed

3⊗3=3¯a⊕6stensor-product33direct-sumsubscript¯3asubscript6s3\otimes 3=\bar{3}_{\rm a}\oplus 6_{\rm s} (2)

The light diquark in the 6-plet is symmetric, in the 3¯¯3\bar{3}-plet antisymmetric.

Figure 1a shows the symmetric 20-plet, which contains the well-known baryon decuplet and a sextet of charmed baryons. In addition to Ξc​c+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐\Xi_{cc}^{+} and Ξc​c++superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐absent\Xi_{cc}^{++}, a Ωc​c+superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐𝑐\Omega_{cc}^{+} (with two charmed and one strange quarks) and a Ωc​c​c++superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐𝑐𝑐absent\Omega_{ccc}^{++} are expected but not yet observed. All baryons in the symmetric 20-plet in the ground state have a total spin J=3/2𝐽32J=3/2. The three quark pairs are symmetric with respect to (w.r.t.) their exchange, in particular the pair of light quarks is symmetric w.r.t. their exchange, they have SUF(3) multiplicity 6. Baryons with three charmed quarks have not yet been discovered.

Figure 1b shows the mixed symmetry 20-plet of heavy baryons. In the ground state they have J=1/2𝐽12J=1/2. Baryons with one heavy quark occupy the second layer. The 6-plet and the 3¯¯3\bar{3}-plet are indicated. The sextet in the first floor has a a symmetric light-quark pair, the two light-heavy quark pairs are then antisymmetric in flavor. The 3-plet in the first floor has an antisymmetric light-quark pair, the light-heavy quark pairs are then symmetric in flavor.

Finally, there is a fully anti-symmetric 4-plet. It is shown in Fig. 1c. Ground-state baryons have a symmetric spatial wave function. A spin wave function of three fermions has mixed symmetry. A fully symmetry, a fully antisymmetric and a mixed-symmetry wave function cannot be coupled to a fully symmetric wave function. Hence ground-state baryons cannot be in the 4-plet. Only excited baryons can have a fully antisymmetric flavor wave function. Below, in Section 5, the wave functions and their symmetries are discussed in more detail.

3 Excited baryons: Selected experimental results

3.1 BaBar, BELLE and LHCb:

Most information on heavy baryons stems from three experiments, BaBar, BELLE and LHCb even though many discoveries had already been made before with the Split-Field-Magnet, by the SELEX, UA and LEP experiments at CERN, and by the CDF experiment at FERMILAB. BaBar at SLAC (US) and BELLE at KEK (Japan) study the decays of B𝐵B mesons produced in asymetric e+​e−superscript𝑒superscript𝑒e^{+}e^{-} storage rings with beam energies of 9 (KEK: 7) GeV for electrons and 3.1 (KEK: 4) GeV for positrons resulting in a center-of-mass energy equal to the Υ​(4​S)Υ4𝑆\Upsilon(4S) mass of 10.58 GeV. The LHCb experiment is placed at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN operating at s=13.6𝑠13.6\sqrt{s}=13.6 GeV. The experiment is a single-arm forward spectrometer covering the pseudorapidity range 2≤η≤52𝜂52\leq\eta\leq 5. It is designed for the study of particles containing b𝑏b or c𝑐c quarks. All three detectors have vertex reconstruction capabilities; BaBar and BELLE track charged particles in tracking chambers placed in the 1.5 T magnetic field of a superconducting solenoid. Particle identification is provided by a measurement of the specific ionization and by detection of the Cherenkov radiation in reflecting ring imaging Cherenkov detectors. CsI(Tl)-crystal electromagnetic calorimeters allow for energy measurements of electrons and photons. LHCb is equipped with silicon-strip detector located upstream and downstream of a dipole magnet with a bending power of about 4 Tm. Photons, electrons and hadrons are identified by a calorimeter system consisting of scintillating counters and pre-shower detectors, and an electromagnetic and a hadronic calorimeter. Muons are identified by a system composed of alternating layers of iron and multiwire proportional chambers.

In the following we discuss three important results from these experiments that demonstrate the capabilities of the detectors.

3.2 Observation of Ωc∗0​(2770)superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐absent02770\Omega_{c}^{*0}(2770) decaying to Ωc0​γsuperscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐0𝛾\Omega_{c}^{0}\gamma by BaBar:

The Babar experiment studied the inclusive reaction e+​e−→Ωc∗0​X→superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐absent0𝑋e^{+}e^{-}\to\Omega_{c}^{*0}\,X where X𝑋X denote the recoiling particles BaBar:2006pve . Ωc0superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐0\Omega_{c}^{0} baryons are identified via different decay modes and reconstructed with a mass resolution σRMS=13subscript𝜎RMS13\sigma_{\rm RMS}=13 MeV. The γ𝛾\gamma is reconstructed in the Ωc0superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐0\Omega_{c}^{0} CsI(Tl) calorimeter. Figure 2 shows the reconstructed Ωc0superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐0\Omega_{c}^{0} and the Ωc∗0superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐absent0\Omega_{c}^{*0} in its Ωc∗0→Ωc0​γ→superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐absent0superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐0𝛾\Omega_{c}^{*0}\to\Omega_{c}^{0}\gamma decay. Obviously, the Ωc∗0​(2770)superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑐absent02770\Omega_{c}^{*0}(2770) is equivalent to Δ0​(1232)superscriptΔ01232\Delta^{0}(1232) with the u,d,d𝑢𝑑𝑑u,d,d quarks exchanged by c,s,s𝑐𝑠𝑠c,s,s, and the transition corresponds to the Δ​(1232)→N​γ→Δ1232𝑁𝛾\Delta(1232)\to N\gamma decay.

3.3 First determination of the spin and parity of the charmed-strange baryon Ξc+​(2970)superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐2970\Xi_{c}^{+}(2970) by BELLE.

The BELLE collaboration identified Ξc+​(2970)superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐2970\Xi_{c}^{+}(2970) in the decay chain Ξc+​(2970)→Ξc0​(2645)​π+→Ξc+​π−​π+→superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐2970superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐02645superscript𝜋→superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐superscript𝜋superscript𝜋\Xi_{c}^{+}(2970)\to\Xi_{c}^{0}(2645)\pi^{+}\to\Xi_{c}^{+}\pi^{-}\pi^{+}; Ξc+superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐\Xi_{c}^{+} is reconstructed from its decay into Ξ−​π+​π+superscriptΞsuperscript𝜋superscript𝜋\Xi^{-}\pi^{+}\pi^{+} Belle:2020tom . Due to its mass, Ξc0​(2645)superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐02645\Xi_{c}^{0}(2645) is likely the spin excitation with JP=3/2+superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{+} of the JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+} ground state Ξc0superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐0\Xi_{c}^{0}. The helicity angle in the primary decay, i.e. the angle between the π+superscript𝜋\pi^{+} and the opposite of the boost direction in the c.m. frame both calculated in the Ξc+​(2970)superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐2970\Xi_{c}^{+}(2970) rest frame, proved to be insensitive to some likely JPsuperscript𝐽𝑃J^{P} combinations. However, the predictions for different JPsuperscript𝐽𝑃J^{P}’s vary significantly for the angular distributions in the secondary decay (see Fig. 3).

The analysis shows that quantum numbers JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+} are preferred for Ξc+​(2970)superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐2970\Xi_{c}^{+}(2970). These are the quantum numbers of the Roper resonance. The BELLE collaboration noted that its mass difference to the ΞcsubscriptΞ𝑐\Xi_{c} ground state is about 500 MeV. The same excitation energy is required to excite the Roper resonance N​(1440)𝑁1440N(1440), the Λ​(1600)Λ1600\Lambda(1600) and the Σ​(1660)Σ1660\Sigma(1660), all with JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+}.

3.4 First observation of excited ΩbsubscriptΩ𝑏\Omega_{b} states by LHCb.

The LHCb collaboration searched for narrow resonances in the Ξb0​K−superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑏0superscript𝐾\Xi_{b}^{0}\,K^{-} invariant mass distribution LHCb:2020tqd . The Ξb0superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑏0\Xi_{b}^{0} has a lifetime of (1.48±plus-or-minus\pm0.03)10−12superscript101210^{-12} s, c​τ≈500​μ𝑐𝜏500𝜇c\tau\approx 500\,\mum, which is sufficiently long to separate the interaction and the decay vertices. Four peaks can be seen (Fig. 4), which correspond to excited states of ΩcsubscriptΩ𝑐\Omega_{c}. With the given statistics, quantum numbers can not yet be determined.

4 The mass spectrum of excited heavy baryons

Figure 5 shows the mass spectrum of heavy baryons with a single charm or bottom quark. Established light baryons with strangeness are shown for comparison. The quantum numbers of low-mass heavy baryons are mostly known, for higher-mass states this information is often missing. The masses are given as excitation energies above the ΛΛ\Lambda (ΛcsubscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda_{c}, ΛbsubscriptΛ𝑏\Lambda_{b}) mass.

At the first glance, the spectrum looks confusing. The ΛΛ\Lambda spectrum is crowded, there is a low-mass negative-parity spin doublet, a second doublet – at about the same mass as a ΣΣ\Sigma spin doublet – a pair with JP=1/2−superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{-} and 5/2−5superscript25/2^{-} where a 3/2−3superscript23/2^{-} state seems to be missing, and then a positive-parity doublet with JP=3/2+,5/2+superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript25superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{+},5/2^{+}. In the ΛcsubscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda_{c} spectrum, the higher-mass negative-parity states and the positive-parity doublet are inverted in mass111This inversion was predicted by Capstick and Isgur long before the states were discovered Capstick:1986ter . The 3/2+−1/2+3superscript21superscript23/2^{+}-1/2^{+} hyperfine splitting decreases rapidly when going from ΣΣ\Sigma and ΞΞ\Xi to ΣcsubscriptΣ𝑐\Sigma_{c} and ΞcsubscriptΞ𝑐\Xi_{c} and from ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b} and ΞbsubscriptΞ𝑏\Xi_{b}. It is interesting to note that a similar pattern is observed in mesons: the hyperfine splitting decreases when going from ρ−π𝜌𝜋\rho-\pi to D∗−Dsuperscript𝐷𝐷D^{*}-D and to B∗−Bsuperscript𝐵𝐵B^{*}-B. Also, there is one ΞΞ\Xi 1/2+1superscript21/2^{+} ground state but two states for ΞcsubscriptΞ𝑐\Xi_{c} and ΞbsubscriptΞ𝑏\Xi_{b}. The lowest-mass ΩΩ\Omega has JP=3/2+superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{+}, in the charm sector, two low-mass ΩcsubscriptΩ𝑐\Omega_{c} states are known with JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+} and 3/2+3superscript23/2^{+}, the ΩbsubscriptΩ𝑏\Omega_{b} spectrum has just one low-mass state with JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+}.

5 Heavy baryons as three-quark systems

5.1 The spatial wave function

The orbital wave functions of excited states are classified into two kinds of orbital excitations, the λ𝜆\lambda-mode and the ρ𝜌\rho-mode. In heavy baryons with one heavy quark, the λ𝜆\lambda-mode is the excitation of the coordinate between the heavy quark and the light diquark, and the ρ𝜌\rho-mode is the excitation of the diquark cluster. In light-baryon excitations, the λ𝜆\lambda and ρ𝜌\rho oscillators are mostly both excited, e.g. to lλ=1subscript𝑙𝜆1l_{\lambda}=1, lρ=0subscript𝑙𝜌0l_{\rho}=0 and lλ=0subscript𝑙𝜆0l_{\lambda}=0, lρ=1subscript𝑙𝜌1l_{\rho}=1, the two components of the wave function having a relative ++ or −- sign. In heavy baryons with one heavy quark, the mixing between these two configurations is small.

The two oscillators have different reduced masses, mρsubscript𝑚𝜌m_{\rho} and mλsubscript𝑚𝜆m_{\lambda}:

mρ=mq2,mλ=2​mq​mQ2​mq+mQ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝜌subscript𝑚𝑞2subscript𝑚𝜆2subscript𝑚𝑞subscript𝑚𝑄2subscript𝑚𝑞subscript𝑚𝑄m_{\rho}=\frac{m_{q}}{2}\;\;,\;\;m_{\lambda}=\frac{2m_{q}m_{Q}}{2m_{q}+m_{Q}}. (3)

The ratio of harmonic oscillator frequencies is then given by

ωλωρ=13​(1+2​mq/mQ)≤1.subscript𝜔𝜆subscript𝜔𝜌1312subscript𝑚𝑞subscript𝑚𝑄1\displaystyle\frac{\omega_{\lambda}}{\omega_{\rho}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}(1+2m_{q}/m_{Q})}\leq 1. (4)

In the heavy-quark limit (mQ→∞→subscript𝑚𝑄m_{Q}\to\infty), the excitation energies in the λ𝜆\lambda oscillator are reduced by a factor 33\sqrt{3}.

5.2 Diquarks

We first consider the light diquark. The two light quarks can have either the symmetric flavor structure 𝟔Fsubscript6𝐹\mathbf{6}_{F} or the antisymmetric flavor structure 𝟑¯Fsubscript¯3𝐹\mathbf{\bar{3}}_{F}. The spin of the light diquark can be sq​q=sl=1subscript𝑠𝑞𝑞subscript𝑠𝑙1s_{qq}=s_{l}=1 or sl=0subscript𝑠𝑙0s_{l}=0 leading to a symmetric or an antisymmetric spin wave function. The color part of the wave function is totally antisymmetric. Hence flavor and spin wave functions are linked. In an S𝑆S-wave, scalar (“good” or g) and axial-vector (“bad” or b) diquarks can be formed. The intrinsic quark spins couple to the internal orbital angular momentum lρsubscript𝑙𝜌l_{\rho}, leading to excited diquarks with orbital excitations.

(lρ=0,𝐒)subscript𝑙𝜌0𝐒\displaystyle(l_{\rho}=0,~{}{\bf S}) {sl=0​(𝐀),𝟑¯F​(𝐀),jq​q=0,(g)sl=1​(𝐒),  6F​(𝐒),jq​q=1,(b)casesformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙0𝐀subscript¯3𝐹𝐀subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞0gformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙1𝐒subscript6𝐹𝐒subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞1b\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}s_{l}=0~{}({\bf A})\,,\,\mathbf{\bar{3}}_{F}~{}({\bf A})\,,\,j_{qq}=0\,,\qquad\qquad\ \hfill(\mbox{g})\\ s_{l}=1~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\,\mathbf{6}_{F}~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\ j_{qq}=1\,,\qquad\hfill(\mbox{b})\end{array}\right.
(lρ=1,𝐀)subscript𝑙𝜌1𝐀\displaystyle(l_{\rho}=1,~{}{\bf A}) {sl=0​(𝐀), 6F​(𝐒),jq​q=1,(g)sl=1​(𝐒),𝟑¯F​(𝐀),jq​q=0/1/2,(b)casesformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙0𝐀subscript6𝐹𝐒subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞1gformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙1𝐒subscript¯3𝐹𝐀subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞012b\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}s_{l}=0~{}({\bf A})\,,\,\mathbf{6}_{F}~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\ \,j_{qq}=1\,,\qquad\qquad\hfill(\mbox{g})\\ s_{l}=1~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\,\mathbf{\bar{3}}_{F}~{}({\bf A})\,,\,\ j_{qq}=0/1/2\,,\hfill(\mbox{b})\end{array}\right.
(lρ=2,𝐒)subscript𝑙𝜌2𝐒\displaystyle(l_{\rho}=2,~{}{\bf S}) {sl=0​(𝐀),𝟑¯F​(𝐀),jq​q=2,(g)sl=1​(𝐒),  6F​(𝐒),jq​q=1/2/3,(b)casesformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙0𝐀subscript¯3𝐹𝐀subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞2gformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑙1𝐒subscript6𝐹𝐒subscript𝑗𝑞𝑞123b\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}s_{l}=0~{}({\bf A})\,,\,\mathbf{\bar{3}}_{F}~{}({\bf A})\,,\,\ j_{qq}=2\,,\qquad\qquad\hfill(\mbox{g})\\ s_{l}=1~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\,\mathbf{6}_{F}~{}({\bf S})\,,\,\ \,j_{qq}=1/2/3\,,\hfill(\mbox{b})\end{array}\right.
⋯⋯\displaystyle\cdots

where we have denoted the total angular momentum of the light diquark as jq​qsubscript𝑗𝑞𝑞j_{qq}.

5.3 Coupling of angular momenta

Figure 6 shows how the orbital angular momentum and the diquark spin couple to the total diquark angular momentum jlsubscript𝑗𝑙j_{l}. This in turn couples to the heavy-quark spin sQsubscript𝑠𝑄s_{Q} giving rise to spin doublets (or just spin-1/2 states for jl=0subscript𝑗𝑙0j_{l}=0). Note the ΛΛ\Lambda and ΞΞ\Xi spin doublet with sl=0subscript𝑠𝑙0s_{l}=0 and 3¯Fsubscript¯3F\bar{3}_{\rm F}. In this case the wave function is antisymmetric in spin and flavor, this is a “good” diquark.

Only a few heavy baryons are known with L=2𝐿2L=2: ΛcsubscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda_{c} and ΛbsubscriptΛ𝑏\Lambda_{b} with spin-parity 3/2+3superscript23/2^{+} and 5/2+5superscript25/2^{+}. The other expected states seem to show up only in the higher-mass, less-explored region. The two observed doublets can be assigned to a configuration in which lρ=2subscript𝑙𝜌2l_{\rho}=2, Lλ=0subscript𝐿𝜆0L_{\lambda}=0, and the diquark is in 3¯Fsubscript¯3F\bar{3}_{\rm F} and sl=0subscript𝑠𝑙0s_{l}=0.

The diquark is a “good” diquark. Note that the states Λc​(2860)subscriptΛ𝑐2860\Lambda_{c}(2860), Λc​(2880)subscriptΛ𝑐2880\Lambda_{c}(2880) with spin-parity 3/2+3superscript23/2^{+} and 5/2+5superscript25/2^{+} (L=2𝐿2L=2) are below Λc​(2940)subscriptΛ𝑐2940\Lambda_{c}(2940) with 3/2−3superscript23/2^{-}. The latter state has a “bad” diquark and is excited to L=1𝐿1L=1 in the ρ𝜌\rho oscillator. In this competition, the “good” diquark and λ𝜆\lambda excitation with L=2𝐿2L=2 wins over “bad” diquark and ρ𝜌\rho oscillator even though the orbital angular momentum of Λc​(2940)subscriptΛ𝑐2940\Lambda_{c}(2940) is L=1𝐿1L=1!

Table 3 gives a survey of the coupling scheme of Q​q​q𝑄𝑞𝑞Qqq baryons. The spin and orbital angular momentum of the two light quarks couple to jqsubscript𝑗𝑞j_{q}, and when combined with the heavy-quark spin sQsubscript𝑠𝑄s_{Q}, the final JPsuperscript𝐽𝑃J^{P} results. There are also states with mixed excitations like lρ=1subscript𝑙𝜌1l_{\rho}=1, lλ=1subscript𝑙𝜆1l_{\lambda}=1. These are unlikely to be produced and are not included here. ΛΛ\Lambda and ΞΞ\Xi with sq=0subscript𝑠𝑞0s_{q}=0 and lρ=0subscript𝑙𝜌0l_{\rho}=0 have a “good” light diquark. For the ΛcsubscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda_{c} we denote the light diquark by [u,d]𝑢𝑑[u,d]. Note that also one light and the heavy quark can be antisymmetric in their spin and flavor wave function. We write Σb=[u​b]​ssubscriptΣ𝑏delimited-[]𝑢𝑏𝑠\Sigma_{b}=[ub]s.

5.4 Heavy quark limit

When mQ→∞→subscript𝑚𝑄m_{Q}\to\infty, the heavy quark spin sQsubscript𝑠𝑄s_{Q} is conserved. Due to the conservation of the total angular momentum J𝐽J, also the angular momentum carried by the light quarks is conserved. Hence all interactions which depend on the spin of the heavy quark disappear. Thus, the mass difference within a spin doublet with, e.g., JP=3/2+superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{+} and 1/2+1superscript21/2^{+}, will disappear in the heavy-quark limit. Indeed, the mass differences

MΣ​(1520)​3/2+subscript𝑀Σ15203superscript2\displaystyle\qquad M_{\Sigma(1520)3/2^{+}} −\displaystyle- MΣ​(1190)=230​MeVsubscript𝑀Σ1190230MeV\displaystyle M_{\Sigma(1190)}=230\,{\rm MeV}
MΣc​(2520)​3/2+subscript𝑀subscriptΣ𝑐25203superscript2\displaystyle\qquad M_{\Sigma_{c}(2520)3/2^{+}} −\displaystyle- MΣc​(2455)= 65​MeVsubscript𝑀subscriptΣ𝑐245565MeV\displaystyle M_{\Sigma_{c}(2455)}=\ 65\,{\rm MeV}
MΣb​(5830)​3/2−subscript𝑀subscriptΣ𝑏58303superscript2\displaystyle\qquad M_{\Sigma_{b}(5830)3/2^{-}} −\displaystyle- MΣb​(5820)= 20​MeVsubscript𝑀subscriptΣ𝑏582020MeV\displaystyle M_{\Sigma_{b}(5820)}=\ 20\,{\rm MeV}

decrease as mQsubscript𝑚𝑄m_{Q} becomes large.

6 A guide to the literature

The first prediction of the full spectrum of baryons including charmed and bottom baryons was presented by Capstick and Isgur Capstick:1986ter , three years before the first baryon with bottomness was discovered. The publication remained a guideline for experimenters for now 36 years! Capstick and Isgur used a relativized quark model with a confining potential and effective one-gluon exchange. Based on the quark model, further studies of the mass spectra of heavy baryons were performed. They are numerous, and only a selction of papers can be mentioned here.

Ebert, Faustov and Galkin calculated the mass spectra for orbital and radial excitations and constructed Regge trajectories Ebert:2011kk . Yu, Li, Wang, Lu, and Ya Yu:2022ymb calculated the mass spectra and decays of heavy baryons excited in the λ𝜆\lambda-mode. Li, Yu, Wang, Lu, and Gu Li:2022xtj restricted the calculation - again based on the relativized quark model - to the ΞcsubscriptΞ𝑐\Xi_{c} and ΞbsubscriptΞ𝑏\Xi_{b} families. In their model, all excitations are in the λ𝜆\lambda-mode.

Migura, Merten, Metsch, and Petry Migura:2006en calculated excitations of charmed baryons within a relativistically covariant quark model based on the Bethe-Salpeter-equation in instantaneous approximation. Interactions are given by a linearly rising three-body confinement potential and a flavor dependent two-body force derived from QCD instanton effects. Valcarce, Garcilazo and Vijande Valcarce:2014fma performed a comparative Faddeev study of heavy baryons with nonrelativistic and relativistic kinematics and different interacting potentials that differ in the description of the hyperfine splitting. The authors conclude that the mass difference between members of the same SUF(3) configuration, either 3¯Fsubscript¯3𝐹\bar{3}_{F} or 6Fsubscript6𝐹6_{F}, is determined by the interaction in the light-heavy quark subsystem, and the mass difference between members of different representations is mainly determined by the dynamics of the light diquark.

Chen, Wei and Zhang Chen:2014nyo derive a mass formula in a relativistic flux tube model to calculate mass spectra for ΛΛ\Lambda and ΞΞ\Xi heavy baryons and assign quantum numbers to states whose quantum numbers were not known. Faustov and Galkin Faustov:2020gun assigned flavor- and symmetry dependent masses and form factors to diquarks and calculated the masses of heavy baryons within a relativistic quark-diquark picture. Quantum numbers are suggested for the ΩcsubscriptΩ𝑐\Omega_{c} excitations LHCb:2017uwr ; Belle:2017ext and other states with unknown spin-parities. A further diquark model, again with adjusted diquark masses, is presented by Kim, Liu, Oka, and Suzuki Kim:2021ywp exploiting a chiral effective theory of scalar and vector diquarks according to the linear sigma model.

QCD sum rules have been exploited to study P-wave heavy baryons and their decays within the heavy quark effective theory (see Yang:2019cvw and refs. therein). The low-lying spectrum of charmed baryons has also been calculated in lattice QCD with a pion mass of 156 MeV Bahtiyar:2020uuj . The results - comparing favorably with the data - are compared to earlier lattice studies that are not discussed here.

All calculations reproduce the observed spectrum with good success, with a large number of parameters. For the reader, it is often not easily seen what are the main driving forces that generate the mass spectrum. Clearly, a confinement potential is mandatory, spin dependent forces are necessary. In the following phenomenological part we try to identify the leading effects driving the resonance spectrum.

7 Phenomenology of heavy baryons

We start with a simple observation: masses of baryons increase when a u𝑢u or d𝑑d quark is replaced by an s𝑠s quark (see Table 4). For light baryons, this is known as U𝑈U-spin rule. The constituent s𝑠s-quark mass decreases in heavy baryons. Note that the difference of current quark masses is ms−mn≈124subscript𝑚𝑠subscript𝑚𝑛124m_{s}-m_{n}\approx 124 MeV.

In Table 5 we show the mass difference of the lowest-mass JP=3/2−superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{-} states with (u,d,s,c𝑢𝑑𝑠𝑐u,d,s,c) or (u,d,s,b𝑢𝑑𝑠𝑏u,d,s,b) quarks and the JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+} ground states: The mass differences are surprisingly small. The N​(1520)−N𝑁1520𝑁N(1520)-N mass difference is 580 MeV, much larger than the mass differences seen here. In the table, [ud] represents wave functions with a u,d𝑢𝑑u,d quark pair that is anti-symmetric in spin and flavor. These diquarks are often called good diquarks. The presence of good diquarks leads to a stronger binding. In the 4-plet, all three quark pairs have such a component w.r.t. their exchange. We denote this by [ud,us,ds]. Thus there are three good diquarks in the wave function. This fact leads to the low masses of the 4-plet members. The similarity of the mass splittings supports similar interpretations of the four resonances from Λ​(1520)Λ1520\Lambda(1520) to Ξb​ 3/2−0subscriptsuperscriptΞ0𝑏3superscript2\Xi^{0}_{b\ 3/2^{-}}.

In most publications, both resonances, Λc​(2595)​1/2−subscriptΛ𝑐25951superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2595)1/2^{-} and Λc​(2625)​3/2−subscriptΛ𝑐26253superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2625)3/2^{-}, are discussed as 3-quark baryons. However, Nieves and Pavao Nieves:2019nol have studied these two resonances in an effective field theory that incorporates the interplay between Σc(∗)​π−N​D(∗)subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑐𝜋𝑁superscript𝐷\Sigma^{(*)}_{c}\pi-ND^{(*)} baryon-meson dynamics and bare P𝑃P-wave c​u​d𝑐𝑢𝑑cud quark-model state and suggest that these two resonances are not heavy quark symmetry spin partners. Instead, they see Λc​(2625)​3/2−subscriptΛ𝑐26253superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2625)3/2^{-} as a dressed three-quark state while Λc​(2595)​1/2−subscriptΛ𝑐25951superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2595)1/2^{-} is reported to have a predominant molecular structure. Nevertheless, the two states Λc​(2625)​3/2−subscriptΛ𝑐26253superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2625)3/2^{-} and Λc​(2595)​1/2−subscriptΛ𝑐25951superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2595)1/2^{-} obviously form a spin doublet.

The mass shift in H atoms between the two ground states with electron and proton spins parallel or antiparallel is called hyperfine splitting. We borrow this expression to discuss the difference between the ground states with all three quark spins adding to J=3/2𝐽32J=3/2 (and belonging to the symmetric 20-plet) and with those having J=1/2𝐽12J=1/2 (that belong to the mixed-symmetrx 20-plet). We thus compare masses of the fully symmetric 20ssubscript20𝑠20_{s}-plet with those from the 3¯¯3\bar{3}-plet or 6-plet within the 20msubscript20𝑚20_{m}-plet (see Table 6). The two configurations differ by the orientation of the heavy-quark spin relative to the spin of the light diquark. According to the heavy-quark-spin symmetry, this mass difference has to vanish with mQ→∞→subscript𝑚𝑄m_{Q}\to\infty. In the Table we assume constituent quark masses of 0.15 GeV (u,d𝑢𝑑u,d), 0.3 GeV (s𝑠s), 1.25 GeV (c𝑐c) and 4.1 GeV (b𝑏b).

The JP=3/2+superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{+} states have a fully symmetric flavor wave function, the JP=1/2+superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{+} states have an antisymmetric quark pair (a good diquark) that is indicated in the list. Their effect scales with 1/mq1subscript𝑚𝑞1/m_{q}. The mass shift due to the presence of good diquarks is expected for instanton-induced interactions.

7.1 Heavy baryons at higher mass:

Next we discuss the higher-mass negative-parity states. In light-baryon spectroscopy, there are seven negative-parity ΛΛ\Lambda states expected in the first excitation level: two singlet states with JP=1/2−,3/2−superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript23superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{-},3/2^{-}, two octet states with intrinsic total quark spin s=1/2𝑠12s=1/2 and JP=1/2−,3/2−superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript23superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{-},3/2^{-}, and a JP=1/2−,3/2−,5/2−superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript23superscript25superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{-},3/2^{-},5/2^{-} triplet with s=3/2𝑠32s=3/2. In light baryons, both λ𝜆\lambda and ρ𝜌\rho oscillator are coherently excited. In heavy-quark baryons, the two oscillators decouple, and the λ𝜆\lambda and ρ𝜌\rho modes are well separated. The low-lying spin-doublet of P𝑃P-wave ΛQsubscriptΛ𝑄\Lambda_{Q} states is dominated by a λ𝜆\lambda-mode excitation, the other five expected states are excited in the ρ𝜌\rho mode.

Unfortunately, only one negative-parity state at a higher mass has been reported, the Λc​(2940)​3/2−subscriptΛ𝑐29403superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2940)3/2^{-}. Its mass is 653 MeV above the Λc+superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda_{c}^{+}. We interpret this state as lρsubscript𝑙𝜌l_{\rho} excitation with a diquark spin s=1𝑠1s=1. The Λ​(1690)​3/2−Λ16903superscript2\Lambda(1690)3/2^{-} is only 570 MeV above the ΛΛ\Lambda, it is excited in both the λ𝜆\lambda and the ρ𝜌\rho mode.

The mass of Λc​(2940)​3/2−subscriptΛ𝑐29403superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2940)3/2^{-} (with intrinsic orbital angular momentum L=1𝐿1L=1) is above the masses of the positive-parity states Λc​(2860)​3/2+subscriptΛ𝑐28603superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2860)3/2^{+} and Λc​(2880)​5/2+subscriptΛ𝑐28805superscript2\Lambda_{c}(2880)5/2^{+} (having L=2𝐿2L=2). Yet, the mass of Λ​(1690)​3/2−Λ16903superscript2\Lambda(1690)3/2^{-} falls well below the masses of Λ​(1890)​3/2+Λ18903superscript2\Lambda(1890)3/2^{+} and Λ​(1820)​5/2+Λ18205superscript2\Lambda(1820)5/2^{+} for reasons discussed above.

8 Pentaquarks

In 2015, the LHCb collaboration reported the observation of two exotic structures in the J/ψ​p𝐽𝜓𝑝J/\psi p system, a broad resonant structure with a Breit-Wigner width of about 200​MeV200MeV200\,\mbox{MeV} called Pc​(4380)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4380P_{c}(4380)^{+} and a narrow state, Pc​(4450)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4450P_{c}(4450)^{+} LHCb:2015yax . The exotic structures were observed in the reaction Λb0→J/ψ​K−​p→superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑏0𝐽𝜓superscript𝐾𝑝\Lambda_{b}^{0}\to J/\psi K^{-}p. An excited three-quark nucleon cannot decay into J/ψ​p𝐽𝜓𝑝J/\psi\,p, this would violate the OZI rule. Hence the minimal quark content is (c​c¯​u​u​d𝑐¯𝑐𝑢𝑢𝑑c\bar{c}uud). The findings met with great interest; the publication is quoted nearly 1500 times (2022, November). Indeed narrow baryonic resonances with hidden charm had been predicted several years before as dynamically generated states Hofmann:2006qx ; Wu:2010vk ; Wu:2012md .

A multitude of different interpretations of the observed structures is offered in the literature, but none is accepted anonymously. There are numerous reviews on tetra- and pentaquarks and their possible interpretations Chen:2016qju ; Chen:2016qju ; Guo:2017jvc ; Olsen:2017bmm ; Brambilla:2019esw ; Liu:2019zoy ; Burns:2022uiv .

With increased statistics, Pc​(4312)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4312P_{c}(4312)^{+} was confirmed and the higher-mass Pc​(4450)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4450P_{c}(4450)^{+} was shown to be split into two narrow overlapping structures, Pc​(4440)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4440P_{c}(4440)^{+} and Pc​(4457)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4457P_{c}(4457)^{+} LHCb:2019kea . The existence of the broad resonance was not confirmed. The data and a fit are shown in Fig. 7 which also displays some relevant thresholds. In addition, a further smaller structure can be seen at 4380 MeV, close to the Σc+∗​D¯0superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑐absentsuperscript¯𝐷0\Sigma_{c}^{+*}\bar{D}^{0} threshold. A narrow structure here is expected in molecular models (see e. g.  Du:2021fmf ), but due to limited statistics there was no attempt to describe it in the recent LHCb analysis LHCb:2019kea . The resonant parameters – including the broad structure at 4380 MeV – are reproduced in Table 7.

Quantum numbers JP=3/2−superscript𝐽𝑃3superscript2J^{P}=3/2^{-} and 5/2+5superscript25/2^{+} were preferred for Pc​(4380)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4380P_{c}(4380)^{+} and Pc​(4450)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4450P_{c}(4450)^{+}. In the later publication LHCb:2019kea , no quantum numbers are determined.

In the reaction Bs0→J/ψ​p¯​p→superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑠0𝐽𝜓¯𝑝𝑝B_{s}^{0}\to J/\psi\,\bar{p}\,p a pentaquark-like structure, named Pc​(4337)+subscript𝑃𝑐superscript4337P_{c}(4337)^{+}, was observed in the J/ψ​p¯𝐽𝜓¯𝑝J/\psi\,\bar{p} and J/ψ​p𝐽𝜓𝑝J/\psi\,p mass distributions LHCb:2021chn . The significance, as determined from a 3-body amplitude analysis, is between 3.1 and 3.7σ𝜎\,\sigma. Its Breit-Wigner parameters are incompatible with the structures observed in ΛbsubscriptΛ𝑏\Lambda_{b} decays. The lighter state at 4312​MeV4312MeV4312\,\mbox{MeV} was not found in this reaction, highlighting the importance of the production mechanism for the formation of these resonances. However, it has been pointed out in Wang:2021crr that in a region with many close-by thresholds, the Breit-Wigner parameters measured in a particular channel may differ significantly from the pole location.

Strange counterparts to these pentaquark states have been searched for by LHCb in the reaction Ξb−→J/ψ​Λ​K−→superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑏𝐽𝜓Λsuperscript𝐾\Xi_{b}^{-}\to J/\psi\,\Lambda K^{-} LHCb:2020jpq . Resonances in the J/ψ​Λ𝐽𝜓ΛJ/\psi\,\Lambda system are denoted by Pc​s0​(4312)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑐𝑠04312P_{cs}^{0}(4312) and have (c​c¯​u​d​s𝑐¯𝑐𝑢𝑑𝑠c\bar{c}uds) as minimal quark content. A peak was found close to the Ξc0​D∗0superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐0superscript𝐷absent0\Xi_{c}^{0}\,D^{*0} threshold with a mass and width given in Table 8.

The J/ψ​Λ𝐽𝜓ΛJ/\psi\Lambda system was also investigated in 2019 by CMS CMS:2019kbn , exploiting the small phase space available in the B-meson decay B−→J/ψ​Λ​p¯→superscript𝐵𝐽𝜓Λ¯𝑝B^{-}\to J/\psi\,\Lambda\bar{p}. The analysis showed that the observed spectrum was incompatible with a pure phase space distribution. Very recently, the LHCb collaboration reported a new analysis of this process LHCb:2022jad . Now, a signal in the J/ψ​Λ𝐽𝜓ΛJ/\psi\,\Lambda subsystem, with preferred quantum numbers JP=1/2−superscript𝐽𝑃1superscript2J^{P}=1/2^{-}, was established at high significance, named Pc​s0​(4338)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑐𝑠04338P_{cs}^{0}(4338). Due to the presence of the second (anti)baryon, the phase space in the B𝐵B-meson decay is too small to access the heavier pentaquark state found in the ΞbsubscriptΞ𝑏\Xi_{b} decay.

These structures have stimulated an intense discussion of the nature of these structures. Do they originate from threshold singularities due to rescattering in the final state leading to a logarithmic branching point in the amplitude? Are they hadronic molecules like the deuteron? Are they compact or triple-quark–diquark systems or states where a c​c¯𝑐¯𝑐c\bar{c} center is surrounded by light quarks?

The peaks are mostly seen very close to important thresholds. Thus they could originate from threshold singularities. We refer to a few publications Guo:2015umn ; Liu:2015fea ; Bayar:2016ftu ; Ali:2017jda . The LHCb collaboration studied this hypothesis and found it incompatible with the data, but the attempts continued Guo:2019twa ; Dong:2020hxe ; Shen:2020gpw ; Nakamura:2021qvy .

Very popular are interpretations as bound states composed of charmed baryons and anti-charmed mesons or of charmonium states binding light-quark baryons. The pentaquark states are then seen to be of molecular nature and be bound by coupled-channel dynamics Eides:2015dtr ; Guo:2019fdo ; Du:2019pij ; Xu:2020gjl ; Chen:2020kco ; Chen:2020uif ; Wu:2021caw ; Lu:2021irg ; Du:2021fmf ; Zhu:2021lhd ; Malabarba:2021taj ; Yalikun:2021bfm . Diquark-triquark models were studied Zhu:2015bba ; Ali:2019npk ; Shi:2021wyt ; Azizi:2021utt , and sum rules are exploited in Refs. Wang:2019got ; Wang:2020eep .

9 Concluding remarks:

The study of hadrons with heavy quarks has developed into a fascinating new field of particle physics. Particular excitement is due to the discovery of unconventional structures that are hotly debated. But also the “regular” heavy hadrons yield very useful information on the interactions of quarks in the confinement region.
